awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Resource-Constrained Optimal Learning Framework for Post-Seismic Regional Building Damage Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research that will contribute new knowledge related to resource allocation for post-seismic building damage assessment, promoting the progress of science and preserving the national welfare. During emergency relief operations after an earthquake or other disaster, it is critical to accurately assess the infrastructural damage across the impacted region. Critical resources must be allocated quickly, before labor-intensive reconnaissance surveys are able to inspect each building. Thus, certain inspections should be prioritized in order to deliver an optimal damage assessment survey in time to benefit first-response relief efforts. This award supports fundamental research to develop a mathematical modeling framework to guide inspection teams through post-seismic reconnaissance missions. This new approach will holistically identify buildings to be prioritized for inspection and design inspection schedules to efficiently visit these buildings with limited time and inspection crew members. Results from this research will expedite regional hazard damage assessment, which will improve disaster management and thereby help save human lives, ensure ethical resource allocation, and preserve the welfare of our society. The project will prepare future civil engineers, mathematicians and statisticians with multi-disciplinary knowledge, and will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research which positively impact engineering education.

This research integrates concepts from statistical and optimal learning with models for routing and scheduling. These two aspects have been extensively studied separately, but never jointly. This knowledge gap poses a serious challenge to the guidance of inspection teams, which collect information in the field subject to resource constraints. The research team will develop an integrated modeling framework which bridges optimal learning and combinatorial optimization to identify inspection routes and schedules that maximize the predictive power of machine learning models for post-seismic building damage assessment. The new methodology will be validated on real-world benchmarks, including data from the 2011 Chile and 2015 Nepal earthquakes, as well as a regional earthquake simulation testbed for the San Francisco Bay. The results will improve crisis management, while also providing new insights into other domains (such as health and disease control) that face a tight tradeoff between data expense and information gain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Immediately following a major earthquake, authorities have to quickly identify high-risk areas for evacuation, debris clearance, and other efforts. Reconnaissance teams have to rapidly assess structural damage throughout the affected region with the help of on-ground inspections. This is a time-consuming process, and with only 8-10 hours for the entire survey, it becomes important to carefully select which buildings will be inspected.

The goal of these inspections is not to mitigate the damage – that is done later based on the results of the survey. Rather, the goal of the reconnaissance effort is to collect data. The inspectors should visit those buildings that can provide the most useful information about the region as a whole. This necessarily involves some sense of data diversity. For example, inspectors should make sure to visit some residential buildings, hotels, schools, and industrial areas, simply because these building types have very different characteristics, and each type contributes something to the big picture. Data diversity is also geographical: we should aim to visit at least some sites in every part of the region, again to build a comprehensive picture of the effects of the earthquake. At the same time, some sites (such as those closest to the epicenter) are clearly more important than others. These are just some of the considerations and tradeoffs involved.

This research project delivered new methodology for designing routes for inspection teams in a way that improved the quality and predictive power of the collected data. The project combined elements of statistics and transportation science, posing and solving a new type of logistics problem where a vehicle was tasked with data collection rather than more traditional business objectives, and performance was evaluated using statistical measures of data quality rather than demand served. A major focus of the research was on solution techniques that could be implemented efficiently with the aid of standard optimization software packages. The new methods were tested in a realistic simulation environment using state-of-the-art earthquake data, and proved capable of identifying superior routes among regions with several hundred buildings, in situations where the time limit allowed inspection of no more than twenty. These routes can be easily visualized and interpreted by decision-makers. The project also studied more theoretical questions related to the design of approximate algorithms with the ability to handle larger problems.

The project supported the completion of four research papers and the graduate education of two Ph.D. students. One of these students subsequently won a prestigious dissertation award from his university based largely on his work on the project. The results were disseminated at several major research conferences.
